CHEMMAT 100.Name: Anonymous
Content: One of the best papers ive taken at UoA. If you allready know a little bit about basic physics/chemistry it should be an easy paper for you. Mark and  Michelle both do a good job explaining, and out a real life application twist to the paper. The small experiments were fun and enjoyable. 10/10 should take this course if youre looking for a gen ed/fill science paper

CHEMMAT 100.Name: Anonymous
Content: Relatively easy course if you already know a bit about physics and chemistry. Quite chill lectures.  Exam was fairly simple
Mark is alright, but he doesn't post his notes online so you'll have attend the lectures.
Michelle ('Nanogirl') is a great and engaging lecturer.
Content isn't the most interesting but there are definitely some real world relateable stuff

CIVIL 702.Name: Anonymous
Content: The course was too tough. Students have to do assignments every week which took 3 or 4 days to complete each assignment and each assignment only contributes around 1% of the final mark. Sometimes, the lecturer forgot that we are students, not the world-class researchers or scientist.

CIVIL 703.Name: Anonymous
Content: Grades are based on cpuple of individual and team projects plus soem assignemnt. Tutorials are in good quality. Hard to get > A- mark.

CIVIL 703.Name: Anonymous
Content: Not much learning, apart from MS project use

CIVIL 705.Name: Anonymous
Content: easy paper

CIVIL 716.Name: Anonymous
Content: Very interesting topics and good professors. You get to learn the concepts of engineering risk management from the ISO 31000 guidelines. Some concepts are thought very theoretically and can be hard to grasp in practice. Feedback were poor on assignments, which made it hard to improve. Students should actively seek feedback. The assignments requires the student to work independently. This semester we had one group project with a on-going project from a company which enhanced the learning.

CIVIL 721.Name: Anonymous
Content: Liam and his PHD students like arman are great at teaching. they really push you to do their best. course is hard but not too bad if you do the work and put in the effort.

CIVIL 721.Name: Antony
Content: I had Pender as our foundations lecturer. His notes are awesome (definitely make studying a lot easier) but the course content can be a bit difficult at times. There are several guest lecturers throughout the semester, these will be in the exam so best not to skip them .
Definitely recommend foundations if you are keen on getting into geotech type engineering

CIVIL 721.Name: arman is a dick
Content: arman is the cancer of this paper

CIVIL 758.Name: Josh
Content: Pretty decent and helpful paper. Lecture quality is quite poor with tonnes of info, HOWEVER both lecturers are able to help if needed. The big traffic project was pretty cool - would recommend doing well in that and putting the hours into SIDRA practice if you want a good grade overall. Expectations are clear and the quiz/exam wasn't designed to be tricky etc.

CIVIL 758.Name: Anonymous
Content: Easy course. Prakash and subeh are very good lecturers

CIVIL 759.Name: Anonymous
Content: like CIVIL 360 course has the same excellent lectures. highly recommend it

CIVIL 790.Name: Josh
Content: Alright paper in terms of content learned. Lectures by PK were pretty horrible, so not many people (including myself) went. Enginuity competition is great and a lot of fun. Although a metric shit tonne of content, a good grade can still be achieved if you look at the tutorial model answers and make the time to talk to PK and KY about your essay answers. They will point you in the right direction. High averages in all coursework but they don't usually scale down at all as exam average is usually low.

CIVIL 790.Name: Anonymous
Content: ez claps. course was fine, very useful insights from running a virtual construction company. didn't attend all lectures, bit bland.

CIVIL 790.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course is taight really well and very useful if you want to get higher up in the work place and manage contracts instead of sitting in an office and doing design work for your boss. Too bad many people dont see the value of this course

CIVIL 791.Name: Daniel Zhuang
Content: One of the easiest courses in part 4. Yang Zou is an excellent lecturer. He is really good at explaining concepts, and gives us instructions for revision. Just stay on top of the work and this course will boost your GPA.

CIVIL 791.Name: Anonymous
Content: Yang is a quality lecture UoA Engineering is lucky to have him. This course is great, 3 assignments make up half of your grade all of which the average mark (in 2019 at least) is around 80% not hard at all to go into the exam with a 95+% grade and the exam is just rope learning very easy to do well if you give it any time. If not you'll still do fine, i didn't go to a single lecture and came out ok. The actual content can be interesting at times, however it could do with a bit more actual industry related content and a bit more focus on construction than it currently has, rather then spend half the course going over correct H&S practices like every other  vaguely construction related course at UoA imo. Overall id definately rank this as one of if not the best part IV elective course in civil.

CIVIL 791.Name: Anonymous
Content: I didn't find the course very relevant to industry, although I found the guest lectures interesting. Health and safety was quite obvious to anyone who had undertaken a practical internship. Could have done with more exam questions which required thinking rather than just rote learning.

CIVIL 791.Name: Antony
Content: Kepa is a pretty good dude, good fun to chat with. There are no notes for this class, so best to go to lectures and take your own nots. There is a group project (you submit a construction tender) which is a massive effort, it helps if you have had experience with construction methodology or have access to tenders which you can work from. Would recommend for someone looking to enter the construction management side of engineering, particularly large construction works

CIVIL 791.Name: Anonymous
Content: easy concepts, not much help/guidance provided for studying with the exam. TA's are pretty useless. Overall a bit inconsistent and unorganised. course has a lot of potential to be relevant for industry but doesn't reach it. had much higher expectations.

ENVENG 701.Name: Above Average Joe
Content: Good course content with solid concepts to grasp.
Elizabeth was pretty decent but she left in 2013.

Her replacement Matthew Davis from Auckland Council was frankly abysmal. He did not give back our assignments ever. We got our grades back in mid August 2015. The University tried their best to deal with it best they can. They were generous in their marking and have pretty much promised us that Mr Davis will not be teaching the course in 2016 (Thank you Part 3 students!).
Overall I felt like I learnt a lot from this course. A lot of it was from group work and independent study. I am sure the course will get a lot better in 2016.

ENVENG 740.Name: WEI IS THE MAN
Content: great course taught by a great lecturer. I loved learning about the content.

ENVENG 740.Name: Wei
Content: This course is so well organised and taught by one of the most caring and approachable lecturers at this university. I would highly recommend this course very useful content taught by an excellent teacher

ENVENG 740.Name: Bless Wei
Content: Wei is the best lecturer out of the entire environmental engineering staff, if not all engineering disciplines. He is one of the nicest, most thoughtful teachers out. The content doesn't even matter cause you'll just end up so completely absorbed his loveliness that you wont be able to pay any attention to the course. Marks for this paper are comprised of 3 assignments, and would probably take as much effort to pass as writing 3 ROLs (bless wei). Seriously though this is a very useful course for anyone wanting to develop there knowledge of wastewater treatment and is made oh so much better by having the most considerate and helpful member of the entire uoa staff teaching it

ENVENG 740.Name: WEI
Content: Why are all the posts about wei? oh wei me too imma just say this man is one of the most caring, helpful and approachable lecturers i have ever come across. I really enjoyed this course. This man is an asset to the university

ENVENG 740.Name: wei qin zhuang
Content: one of the best courses i've taken at this university. It's significantly influenced by the fact its taught by one of the most genuine, caring and approachable lectures at the university. I hope the university sees all theses reviews about wei and gives him a raise lol cause he's an asset

ENVENG 740.Name: Anonymous
Content: Great Course by a great lecturer, well informed and lecture packed in a fun way. The assignment needs some extra effort.

ENVENG 740.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course is very useful if you want to enter the wastewater engineering Industry and is taught by a great lecturer. However, in 2019 he changed the course to include two assignments with weighting 45% and 55% respectively. These assignments were very time consuming and scary due to high percentage. Wei is nice and passing these assignments should be alright. Lectures are good but rarely relate to what is required in the assignment.

ENVENG 740.Name: Anonymous
Content: brilliant course. brilliant lecturer. i would recommend to anyone wanting to develop their knowledge in wastewater treatment

CIVIL 201.Name: Jon Snow
Content: they've made the exam super hard, fuck u civil 201

CIVIL 201.Name: Run Away
Content: RIP

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course is so poorly organised its an absolute joke. We jumped back and forth through the book, no lecture recordings, no piazza communication, very little email communication and minimum learning resources provided. The actual content in the course is fairly easy and arguably interesting but it felt like every single practical assessment or assignment we were simply left in the dark without any clear instruction on what to do.

Finally the exam, the 2016 exam was by a country mile the worst written exam I have sat in my life. The variation in difficulty from year to year is ridiculous. The 2015 exam was insanely easy and the 2016 exam I'm sure will result in well over half the class failing.

Its a pity because now all they are going to have to do is scale everyone up which is a pity because us students who actually went to every lecture, studied all the content and did all the assignments, worksheets and past papers now need to settle for a scaled up B where if we took the paper last year we'd be getting an easy A+.

I think its time for a new set of staff to take over this course (with the exception of Doug who did a great job for the 4 lectures we had with him), it has so much potential and is very important especially since a lot of us will be using surveying skills in our upcoming summer work hours. However the lack of enthusiasm, communication and overall fairness has really left the 2016 group of students rethinking their choice to take civil.

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: I no longer look before I cross the road

CIVIL 201.Name: Failure
Content: GG... see ya next year Tam

CIVIL 201.Name: Donald "Get him out of here" Trump
Content: Some say Tam is still marking L4 to this very day

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: If you're looking for consistency you're in luck, because this course will consistently let you down and make you want to give up on it all. Overall disorganisation and miscommunication makes this course about as enjoyable as having to dig your own grave, which this course actually makes you want to do.

Tam (lecturer and course coordinator) - is pivotal to this course and takes about 80% of the lectures. His course notes are a complete mess, with large chucks of unnecessary information. My tip, try to condense it yourself into logical sections, otherwise you'll be stretched when it comes to revising, his section of the exam tends to be worked problems (ie: Horizontal arcs, rise/fall levelling) so being able to know where to apply the content is helpful. Beware though, Tam isn't the most tech savvy guy and lecture recordings are not at always reliable, and they often contain faults (not recording his voice). It also takes Tam at least a week to upload the recordings, meaning that it is easy to fall behind if you don't make the lecture. Make sure to nag him about this early on otherwise he will continue this and even forget to record (his argument being that students should attend lectures no matter what because its not like some people have jobs and also need to work to be able to afford to even go to uni). Piazza communication was virtually nonexistent, however Tam mentioned that this would change for 2019 onwards with TA's helping out (whole good that does now). A positive perhaps is that the labs and field day that he runs are moderately enjoyable and a refreshing break from lectures.

Doug (lecturer) - takes the transport section of the course. In stark contrast to Tam's notes, Doug's are condensed and follow a structural format. Doug makes its clear what he expects from you and what he wants you to know. He does go off on unnecessary tangents on topics not directly impactful to the subject at hand.
In summary, don't let this course get to you too much, it may make you question your decision to take civil engineering, but if you can get through this joke of a course you can get through anything.

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: 42% average on Test 1. A whole bunch of trig, with a few labs on actually using land surveying equipment. Shit's boring as fuck, and they try to cram so much into the tests and exams, leaving you with no time to finish anything.

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: Tests and exams are ridiculously long. Also you need to memorise a lot of stuff for short-answer questions. Oh and there's trig galore so you'll need to keep quite a few formulae in your head.

Tam has a sense of humour but doesn't seem to know how to work the lecture recording system. George is a bit sleep-inducing but at least he put some lecture recordings up. Overall, paper is lacking in organisation.

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: The old fogey doesn't know how to use cecil properly, neither piazza, so you get shit all support. Lectures are not recorded (mostly) so miss lectures and you're fucked for the exams and tests. However, content is actually kinda easy, so studying for exams and such is common sense.

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: I got 80% in the first test. Was fully prepared for whats in the exam based on what he has taught in class and what is expected from past papers. Went into the exam, he creates the most stupid hard question which allows you to do 30% of the test. If you could not do the first bit of the super hard question which is worth 2%, you can no longer 30% of the rest of the exam. Most stupid way to lay out an exam, all other previous years never had a test this hard before. Feel as if he was out to get us.
Considering you need 40% in the final exam to pass this course, losing 30% worth which you can do, just because you couldn't do the first small part is not fair.

The same lecturer took us for parts of CIVIL 220 and made his section in that SUPER HARD AS FUCK as well. Considering he taught us something which is reflected in nearly throughout all past year papers, then hits us with a question completely out of perspective. Really man, did you really have to.
secondly, lecturers were not recorded at all, but tbh i got the same results as people who didnt come to lectures. so meeh

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: Such a disorganised course . I learnt most of the course myself. A BETTER LECTURER IS REQUIRED . This paper could've been a lot easier if there was a lecturer who could actually teach....

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: lol

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: Easier than average exam in 2019. Probably to make up for that horrible first test (I got 35% average was 42%). Tam should not be lecturing period, its painful to watch. Project was full of mistakes so many of us had to redo sections though Tam did most of the project for us anyway. Every time I see a triangle now I get PTSD

CIVIL 201.Name: Stephen Hawking's Ghost
Content: Beep

CIVIL 201.Name: Josh
Content: 1st test was pretty good, second test was RIDICULOUSLY long. Everything extremely poorly organised and mostly a pisstake. Just pay attention in the lectures, do the assignments and hope you get an exam like 2015 Semester 1. REQUEST EARLY FOR LECTURES TO BE RECORDED. He doesn't do it by himself. Also little help on piazza.

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: Love the course

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: GG
Exam was surprisingly easy for some reason. Maybe because expectations were so low

CIVIL 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: Lots of trigonometry, but most concepts are pretty much common sense if you get your head around them.

CIVIL 201.Name: Finished Level
Content: easiest paper along with civil 210 i have ever sat in my life. tam is a great lecturer and knows how to survey. i learned lots from tam.

CIVIL 211.Name: Anonymous
Content: Exam was bloody hard. GGWP

CIVIL 211.Name: Anonymous
Content: I don't know who were the phd students that gave lectures from previous years but this phd student K this year just gives really bad lectures. He just ruins the whole paper from the beginning. ;(  Let's not talk about his accent, but his pace of lecturing is not reasonable. He talks like he is really nervous and as if he only wants to give us the stuff from his notes instead of teaching us. Just my personal opinion. I'm pretty happy with everything else.

CIVIL 211.Name: Josh
Content: Really difficult concepts. James Lim saved this course for me with the exam, however I think he let Victor take too much control with the test question. Not sure if Victor will teach in 2016 but I'm sure he has learned heaps. Go to all the extra tutorials and pester both James and Victor and till your issue is resolved :)

CIVIL 211.Name: Anonymous
Content: The course is well organized. Good practice questions and well written coursebook, that really helps.
Krishanu taught really well, I enjoyed his part. Matt also explained well but his part was bit difficult. Overall happy with everything.

CIVIL 221.Name: Josh
Content: Liam is a really good lecturer and if you give him respect, he will respect you back and help you with whatever you need. The project for 2015 was too confusing IMO. Just go to the lectures and make 100% sure you understand concepts rather than past exam questions.

CIVIL 221.Name: Anonymous
Content: If you’re the type of student whose only intention is to do the bare minimum and pass, then Liam is an absolute fiend in the sense that if you expect him to grant leniency on your assessment answers, he will end you with a big fat fail grade. If you’re a student with a poor work ethic, then expect Liam to be your worst nightmare because you will not pass his course. Unfortunately, I am this type of student. I tried to juggle fulltime work alongside a fulltime civil engineering degree because I wanted to get away from a toxic parental home but still get to earn my degree. I sat this paper for the first time in 2016 with twenty hours of study feeling confident that Liam would grant a passing grade by giving pity marks to my working as I had successfully done so with other courses. BIG MISTAKE. I failed miserably. I even tried to pass by claiming aegrotat from the stress nose bleed in the exam. I resat the paper last year in 2017 with 20 hours of study and felt that this time I would at least pass. I even felt confident that I would pass since I had filled in most of the questions in the paper. BIG MISTAKE. I failed again. And now, this year will be my final allowable attempt to pass. I feel like I’m not learning from my mistakes because I’m still working fulltime while studying for this degree and I know that there is a very real chance that I can still fail this course regardless of how much I study. As I’m typing this review under the overdose of Ritalin I just took I truly cannot help but express my desperation in the only way I can think of. I know that if I fail this course again I will be expelled from the engineering degree. Despite the amount of study I am doing, I cannot help but feel that there is still a very strong likelihood I can fail because of how strict the passing criterion for this course is. I realise that I am in this predicament of my own accord. I have only myself to blame for this. At the end of the day, Liam is just truly dedicated to ensuring that none of his students pass without truly understanding the key concepts requisite to any professional engineer; Liam’s commitment to this course is second to none. There is not a professor I have come across in my four years of tertiary education that even comes close to the level of dedication this man has for delivering quality course content. That is why I can only rate this course as being 5/5 overall. My only advice to those of you who can relate to my situation is to NEVER UNDERESTIMATE what it truly takes to pass this course. Study HARD for this course, go to EVERY lecture, pay ATTENTION to everything, and truly COMMIT to this course because failing this course twice is a very real outcome. If you think you can pass this course by doing the bare minimum, you’re on your way to contemplating suicide because that’s what you’re going to be feeling if you end up on your third attempt at this course.

CIVIL 221.Name: Anonymous
Content: one of the best second year courses. Liam is really good.

CIVIL 221.Name: Anonymous
Content: REMEMBER THIS LECTURERS NAME LOL.
Content is relatively easy but the questions he asks are just as much difficult. Make sure you understand the roots of the topic rather than focusing on how to answer past questions.

CIVIL 221.Name: Anonymous
Content: Liam is very good lecturer if you dont get on his bad side. pretty sure he hated our cohort tho haha

CIVIL 221.Name: Anonymous
Content: Liam is the man very good lecturer clearly explains the concept

CIVIL 250.Name: Anonymous
Content: This is literally the easiest paper iv ever sat, all tests and exams are exactly the same every year

CIVIL 250.Name: Josh
Content: Pretty interesting course. James didn't want to teach this year so Steel was really boring for me. Do as many practice questions as possible and for concrete in particular, compile all of the past exam questions and answers and go through that a few times a day after reading through the coursebook.

ENVENG 244.Name: Anonymous
Content: Too much irrelevant content. Assignments helped with the learning for calculation questions but there was far too much theory content (esp in Anthea's section) which was not examinable. Wish they had concise notes to study from rather than memorizing the 10 billion lecture slides of 70% useless information!

ENVENG 244.Name: Anonymous
Content: You know that one course each semester that is particularly poor? Well, welcome to ENVENG 244 - the literally shit course (and normal water quality too to be fair). The course where not even the lecturers know what's going on. Where sometimes, a lecturer might not even show up without warning. Where lecturers have to assume their content isn't in the test because they haven't been asked to write any questions. "Disorganised" some might call it.

You start with Naresh - a nice guy, pretty good at explaining stuff, but he has his flaws. His softly spoken manner might be a little sleepy, but that's hardly unusual, and he gets credit for being understandable. But his communication in general needs improvement. To this day, most of us still don't know how much we have to do to get the 2% piazza contribution marks, or when the deadline is - it's not documented anywhere. And his communication to other lecturers doesn't seem to flash hot either from the student's perspective.
Briefly on the note of piazza: Think again if you were expecting questions to be answered by lecturers - it isn't that common.
Next lecturer: Wei-Qin. 10/10, a champ. He lifted this course.

And then you finish up with Lokesh and Ajit. The latter is hard to hear, between the combination of the microphone being too far from his mouth, and his accent being really thick (which don't get me wrong isn't a flaw, just needs to be accounted for). Neither really seemed to "get" the students, and the lack of understanding from the former for why attendance was low for his lecture was a bit ignorant really - we have 4 other courses, and it was a bit of a hellish day.

Final note: giving marks for attendance is an unfortunate necessity. If the lectures were really good, it would be unnecessary. Similarly, saying you will be taking attendance on a particular day, but never actually doing so, is not cool.
Overall, the content is good and I think I could even enjoy it, there just needs to be some improvements around the staff and a bit more understanding.

ENVENG 244.Name: Josh
Content: All lecturers spoke in a monotone which made it very hard to pay attention, however content was really interesting and enjoyable to study. Lab reports were extremely unfair in the marking (what was expected vs what we were actually told to do) as well as being too large for 7% each. Test and exam were both pretty straightforward however my exam was marked really strictly with missing carry-over marks and not much tolerance overall, unlike the test marking. Overall, good enough and interesting enough to justify doing environmental engineering as a career choice (as part of Geotechnical Engineering even), also highlights the importance of environmental engineers and their need in society vs structural engineers.

ENVENG 244.Name: Anonymous
Content: The only enviro course you'll have to take if you're a reasonable human and decide to continue as a structural engineer rather than environmental.
There were three lecturers:
-Tumanako
-Febelyn
-Wei

Starting with Tumanako. Overall a good lecturer, not bad to listen to and kind of entertaining. My problem here is the content he taught, and let me tell you the first two weeks are so boring. So far the most redundant content that was taught to me over my 2 years into the degree.

Next there was Febelyn. This is where the course really goes downhill. I truly mean it when I say she is the worst lecturer I've had. She couldn't explain anything to a clear degree and ran out of time to teach her content. She then went on to mess up a question in the test so it was unanswerable. It's kind of a shame because her content wasn't all that boring. I could go on and on about how she should never teach again, but it will take too long...

And best for last, Wei. The 2/5 stars I gave this course for enjoyment instead of 0/5 are solely thanks to Wei. Explained everything perfectly and knew what he talking about. His content was kind of interesting, and he made it very engaging so learning it was much easier.

This was genuinely the worst course (apart from Wei) that I had the displeasure of taking in my second year of engineering. I did not particularly want to do environmental engineering beforehand, and this course really helped me decide that structural will be better for me.

ENVENG 244.Name: Anonymous
Content: Not too bad overall, the labs were quite interesting apart from having to write reports... A lot of memorising is expected

ENVENG 244.Name: Anonymous
Content: WTF is wrong with this university.
They made the Maori section 2 weeks this year. Memorizing the religion of Maori was complete piss.
I didn't take engineering so that I could have someone give me a list of foreign words I could memorise.
Honestly fuck whoever thought it was a good idea to bring in Maori.

ENVENG 244.Name: Anonymous
Content: Not a diffucult course if you remember the key concepts and know the calculations (which are easy) well.
Relatively easy test and exam, the quizzes are annoying though as they have impossible questions...

CIVIL 324.Name: Anonymous
Content: We had Dr Tam Larkin in 2018. Sadly for us this year the course did not end in week 8 like all other years and we were left with Connor Hayden for the last 6 weeks who took us through the computational modelling part of the course. The computational part was very hard especially with how intense the last week of uni is. This left us with no time to revise. On top of that The first part taught by Tam is very concept heavy and all Tam does is take you through derivations of formulas and goes through very little applications so that when it comes to the test you have zero understanding of how to solve the problems. Don't take this course.

CIVIL 324.Name: Anonymous
Content: Out of the the three electives structural dynamics, fluids or geo... do not take this course, was definitely the toughest out of them all. Tam's bit was extremely conceptually tough and you really have no idea what was going to be in the exams or test ( zero hints). Hayden's bit was ok but still you were thrown in the deep end for the PLAXIS project and it was a struggle! Would not recommend this course unless you really really enjoy geo.

CIVIL 324.Name: Antony
Content: I had dr Tam Larkin, good lecturer knows his stuff but expects you to know it just as well. I  heavily suggest staying on top of this subject throughout the semester very difficult to catch up. The class averages for the past few years for the mid sem test have been bellow 50% showing how hard he makes the tests/exams. The lecture notes he provides are comprehensive enough that you should be able to stay on top of the work load, it just takes time

CIVIL 324.Name: Anonymous
Content: Tam Larkin is a great lecturer who knows his stuff well and shows us how to apply that knowledge in the real world. Definitely takes hard work to grasp the topics at the start but once you are there it's a breeze. Lectures are always good and Tam's sense of humour is on point! Thoroughly enjoyed the course and definitely recommend it!

CIVIL 331.Name: Anonymous
Content: horrendous course

CIVIL 331.Name: Anonymous
Content: I think it's time for a new lecturer and a bit of a refresh of this course. No coursebook, no published slides online, and no recordings - yes, you have to write *everything*. Like, we're talking worse than ENVENG 244 in this respect, so try to have a good plan of attack. The test and exam were very hard, so you need bloody good notes to get you through the course. Enjoyment was lifted to 2 stars though because the labs were actually somewhat enjoyable, thanks to good postgrad students running them and quite a lot of short lab exercises. The labs were more like 30 mins, not 2 hrs.

CIVIL 331.Name: Anonymous
Content: No lecture recordings and no coursebook in 2018. Content should be easy, but its difficult to remember something from weeks ago if you didn't write it down. Lectures are decent, however Bruce trying to make them compulsory is retarded. There are no disadvantages of having lecture recordings other than hurting Bruce's ego.

CIVIL 331.Name: Anonymous
Content: all lecture content taught on the whiteboard, no lecture slides and no lecture recordings. Test marking inconsistencies and hard content

CIVIL 331.Name: Anonymous
Content: Another 10 point course that wants to be one of the "important" papers. Bruce goes all over the place during lectures and only answers questions not covered in the lectures. Really biased about attendance (not all of us are just fucking lazy Bruce) holding information that could save a heap of us in Piazza. The tutorial solutions provides NO insightful/learning explanations as to how the fuck he got the numbers. Just get your C and move on.

CIVIL 331.Name: Anonymous
Content: easy course. bruce is a great lecturer one of the best. very easy content not too heavy

CIVIL 331.Name: Anonymous
Content: Contrary to most of the reviews here I really enjoyed this course. Bruce is a great lecturer who explains concepts very clearly and is also of great help in office hours.

It is true there is no coursebook or lecture recordings but if you go to class you will be fine. Bruce writes everything up on the whiteboard and there isn't lots of information to take down so you don't feel like you are scrambling to get information down, you are actually learning as you write.

It is true that in 2017 we had what seemed a harder than usual test and exam, I think mostly due to one question in both the test and exam which tested a key concept which wasn't given much focus on in lectures or tutorials.
But overall for this course as long as you come to class and put some effort in it will be enjoyable and you will do well. If you never come to class you will definitely struggle alot

CIVIL 332.Name: Anonymous
Content: No lecture recordings (done intentionally, mind you). If you want to feel like you want to experience the academic paper equivalent of serving a prison sentence at a US Prison with a 7 foot tall horse dick black bubba cell mate, then take this paper.

CIVIL 332.Name: Anonymous
Content: no lecture recordings and all notes badly set out and confusing to understand. content taught badly

CIVIL 332.Name: Anonymous
Content: Really friendly lecturer, sometimes a little hard to understand through the accent. As of 2019 the lectures are recorded - as was made compulsory by the uni.

The amount of PDE's present LOOKS daunting - especially when you see the final exam appendices, but they are mainly present for understanding. The course is probably evenly balanced between theoretical explanations of behaviours and short calculations (many of which you can work out on the fly using previous course knowledge). The labs and reports are very quick and easy, the photography assignment is a good bit of fun and gives easy marks. The exam was on par if not easier than the test.
Don't knock this course - pay some attention and you'll get through no worries - everything is very relatable to real life behaviours)
(Personal opinion - far easier than 331)

CIVIL 332.Name: Anonymous
Content: very easy course. lecturer is great and helpful. i love fluids easy gpa booster

CIVIL 332.Name: Anonymous

COMPSYS 701.Name: Churrr
Content: Everything in your Compsys life has lead up to this. If 301 turned you into metal, this will turn you to a fucking diamond...
A must take course for all of Compsys.
The paper was separated into a primer assignment (5%), an easy af test (15%), and your project (80%).

Our year had to make a co-processor on an FPGA, and make it interact with an ARM processor running Linux. This was done to speed up a software implementation of an object detection program (no one made it that far lol). We used the Terasic DE1-SOC board for all of this.
The project system:
Input (Encrypted JPEG Image) -> Decryption -> Decompression -> Filtering -> VGA Display and Object detection
The project is composed into 3 phases, our year had:

Phase 1 (20%) - Implement an encryption/decryption algorithm (Trivium) on the FPGA, and get it communicating with your ARM. This was mostly to get us used to the whole FPGA-ARM shazam. The software implementation was very efficient so whatever improvement you had was marginal.
Phase 2 (20%) - Create a co-processor (like the Trivium part, on roidsszz), test the shizz out of the co-processor, make a datasheet, and if you can, get it working with the ARM.
Phase 3 (40%) - Integrate your co-processor and Trivium (if you managed to finish that) all together and make them all work handy dandy. Also write a report to encompass what you did for the project.
From my subjective experience, this paper developed my skills in:
Design > Teamwork > Testing > Documentation > VHDL and C , in a descending order.

Your ability to make things after this will significantly increase (unless if you didn't bother designing anything, and just jumped str8 to it). You'll finally get to understand Quartus and QSYS, and how OP Quartus actually is, we realised a major design fault through observing the various tools Quartus offers such as time quest analyzer, and RTL viewer.
Have fun :)

As a result, the slides were very badly explained by Matthew. Matthew tries, but some people are just not made out for lecturing. The assignment was pretty good, It showed you how to use FreeRTOS, which is quite popular in industry. RTOS concepts were good to learn about as they highlight plenty of issues in most software design.
Avinash is a good lecturer, he does examples in class and often avoids just reading through the slides. His exams questions are quite repetitive, although his content was quite interesting.
Taking this course has made me more aware of the challenges that exist in creating systems that have deadlines, think of this course as an extension to Compsys 303.

Second half was machine learning.. it was reinforcement learning - it was VERY interesting but mohan expects you to be quite a lot smarter than you are so take care lmao. The final exam was easy as shit so you should pass easily.

To the other guy. if you found it so hard you shouldve gone and talked to the lecturers- they basically spoonfed those that turned up the rough areas they were focusing on that we should study. Also Mohans questions are vague repeats of previous semesters with small twists, if you know whats going on you'll be fine. The first half is super helpful and the assignment is very practical, testing on the first half is simple as . Overall not the easiest course but will put you in good standing in the future.

Assignment 1 has nothing to do with the rest of his exam content, so you can learn enough to do the assignment and focus on other courses until exam time.

Ben Tan's part is more well taught, and segways back to previous studies in Distributed Systems (not AI). I found the content pretty interesting personally, and the exam was well managed in terms of content.

COMPSYS 726.Name: Anonymous
Content: Not as bad as previous years, but not the best course. Craig is pretty cool as a lecturer, his lectures mostly provide a high-level overview of the challenges to robot design, but the labs are focussed on ROS, which was covered in the last 20 minutes of the first lecture and never touched in class again. The labs are straightforward but the Turtlebot has many eccentricities, especially when using maps. It is almost impossible to have an accurate map-based operation on the robots with the environment in the lab and the on-board sensors. We were told we would be provided a simulation environment, but this also never came into fruition.  In the end though, the labs were fun.

The main problem comes with how the course is organized. The lab-based assignments only occur in the first 6 weeks, and from then on the course completely changes direction and becomes about matrices and kinematics. The content is very dry, but this would not be a problem if we actually had examples to relate these kinematic concepts to; instead, we spend lecture after lecture on derivations and discussing how to solve a problem instead of doing examples on each topic as we normally do in other courses. The problem sheets did not have any answers released until about Week 11, and when released only contained answers to select questions. The easier questions many times.

There is no practical component to the manipulator design, or even the ANN and Fuzzy logic control sections. ANN and Fuzzy Logic were just thrown in for the sake of saying we covered them, and ANN in particular was assessed based on how well you can memorize the equations.
For Mechatronics students, I would say we learn a lot of this in 706 anyway, and in a way better organized manner, so avoid this.

COMPSYS 726.Name: Anonymous

COMPSYS 726.Name: Sad :'(
Content: Mohan (og lecturer) had left uni early, which caused Matthew (new lecturer) to fill in, and inadvertently fumble through Mohan's content. Matthew tried his best, however, the paper as a whole was very sub-par.

Matthew created a new assignment that uses RoS (robotics framework) which was so timing consuming that he had to chop 60% of the assignment. In my opinion, the original assignment was the equivalent of a 30% project at least.... Most people didn't complete even with the dumbed down requirements. Nitish explained that this was the result of doing the assignment in the 2nd part of the semester, where things were very busy (they should've preempted this).
Nitish taught the majority of the course. Nitish is a good lecturer, and a good one-one tutor, however he is very disorganised. Some examples:

- Released 2 problem sheets (out of 4 total), and an important worked example the week leading to the exam, the worked example was released the day before the exam. The problem sheets and the worked example were worth almost 60% of the exam.
- Covered 40% of new exam material in the last lecture (Week 11). Skipped some important explanations that were required to understand the content because he ran out of time.
- Test took over a month to mark.
- Various mistakes in the problem sheet solutions at different times for various solutions (were later corrected).

Moreover, Nitish tends to explain things using Matlab, and would often release Matlab code as an explanation to an answer in the problem sheet. If you were confused about a certain concept, then you'll spend extra time deciphering what the code does, and stay confused after. The course covers plenty of maths, and derivations, Matlab might show the result, but it doesn't explain the answer as everything is black boxed into pretty APIs.
I do not recommend this paper, at all... I got some nice keywords to look into in the future, and my matrix math is improved, other than that, nothing.

Content: Just want to take a moment to commend the unsung hero of all the first year lecturers, Gerard Rowe. He wasn't in it for the fame; he didn't juggle machetes or crack jokes, he just put his head down and saved the sinking ship Udaya left behind. A true icon.

ELECTENG 101.Name: Anonymous
Content: Gerard was an awesome lecturer. He explained things quickly, clearly and deeply. He made me gain confidence in a subject that I was a little uncomfortable with at high school. Additionally, his responses on Piazza were fast, detailed and consistent. Thank you Gerard!
That being said, it only goes downhill from there in terms of content and lecturers.

As engineers, we generally like our problems to be about problem solving and maths equations. However, we found ourselves having to memorise software development strategies, the sensors and actuators of the curiosity mars rover, various miscellaneous trivia about pace makers and the smart rooms. Now, this wasn't as bad as people make it out to be, but it should be made clearer as to what is examinable and what is not from the START of the course. I did find the summary lecture before the test quite helpful and made this clear, however it was a bit too late by then.

Also, it was difficult for me to take ANYTHING away from the tutorial classes and found all of them to be an utter waste of time. It's a shame that it is the tutorial content that is often examined to reward those who pained themselves to come and strained themselves to stay awake.

ELECTENG 101.Name: Anonymous
Content: I didn't find the course as bad in 2015 as the previous reviews make it out to be, but that may be because I personally found it interesting.

Module 1 was very well taught, and done so by Gerard Rowe (who won the national teaching excellence award in 2004). In my opinion it was the most content-heavy module in the sense that you had to practice lots to get things right. We were given a ton of resource material to practice on.

Module 2 was not taught well at all, Bruce was uninspiring and bland. This is the module where you might suffer if you have no interest. The topics revolved around boolean algebra, combinational/sequential circuits, positional numeral systems, and various misc. trivia regarding computer systems.

Module 3 was the middle ground in terms of teaching quality. I felt Udaya's passion for what he had to talk about (power electronics) and he really did try to teach us the best he could. He brought in examples and real life contraptions that I think would have spiced Module 2 up immensely. Nonetheless, there were times I struggled to understand him due to his accent. I found watching the lecture recordings helpful there as I could slow down and increase the volume.
Labs were great fun.
Overall - an interesting course if you're into this stuff. If you're not, good luck when module 1 is over.

ELECTENG 101.Name: Anonymous
Content: Not sure if I passed this paper or not, but I genuinely found this paper more interesting than ENGGEN 121, which I failed.

ELECTENG 101.Name: Anonymous

ELECTENG 101.Name: literally no.
Content: This is hands-down the worst paper of Part I Engineering. Almost everything about it was terrible, even giving it 1 star is fucking generous. I expected this to be the worst paper in first-year since I hated electricity in high school physics, however I didn't expect it to be that fucking bad. The first of our two lecturers was William. While I appreciate the amount of time he spends on Piazza trying to help students, I found some of his essays and copypastas really annoying. "Hope this helps", more like, yeah nah mate. His lecturing is definitely not for me either, he seems to spend at least 80% of the lecture waffling about absolute nonsense, making me even more confused than I already am with his boring as content. Then we had Bill who is the literal epitome of a man that is just stuck on 0.3x speed irl. When I was watching his lectures on 2x speed, it honestly just seemed like he was still talking at a slower than normal pace. I actually found his content quite interesting, however, he was terrible at explaining the concepts, and like William, seemed to spend most of the lecture talking about useless shit.

I went to a total of 4 lectures in the entire semester. Saying that they were an absolute waste of time would be the biggest understatement of the century. I didn't bother going to or watching William's lectures, for the most part, just copied down the coursebook notes that he posts on CANVAS since they're actually really good. Bill's lectures I actually watched (on 2x speed) since he barely writes any notes. I honestly think that, if the lecturers sped up their pace and cut down on the irrelevant shit they spewed out their mouths, this course could have two lectures a week instead of the dreadful four (two of which being 8AM's, literally why would you do this for the worst and most boring fucking class).

And where do I even begin with the way this course was assessed. "The assessments were a good reflection of your learning", yeah fuck right off. The tests should not at all have been multi-choice, imagine losing 2 marks out of 40 for something so stupid like getting your signs mixed up. And holy fuck was that first test terrible, why does William actually write the most asshole questions. On a more positive note, I actually found the assignments to be very helpful, as it allowed me to review the content each week and see which things I needed to work on, and it lowered how much the exam was worth overall.

Oh, the exam. For a cohort that averages mostly B's, B+'s and A-'s in other papers, if the average is a C, maybe it's not because the students didn't know or understand how to apply the concepts they were taught, rather the exam was just an absolute shitshow. The questions were straight-up weird, and at first it seemed like the contents of the exam were never taught to us. However the worst part was the amount of time given to sit the exam, it was not at all doable in 2 hours. Previous years' exams which were 3 hours long seemed to take much less time to do than this one. Thankfully it's only worth 45%, I dread to know what my final grade would be, had this been a 70% exam like chemmat121. I honestly just hope that this course didn't ruin students' GPA enough to prevent them from getting into their first-choice specialisations, but let's be honest, it probably fucking did.
TL;DR: Everything about this course can fuck off.

ELECTENG 101.Name: Anonymous

ELECTENG 101.Name: Anonymous
Content: Contrary to many students, I personally found 101 quite enjoyable and satisfying when you really get the concepts behind it. Udaya was a nice guy with real passion but I found it hard to focus in his class. He tries to say too much which loses people’s attention. William was excellent, he really nailed circuit analysis and his work on the mcqs, piazza and assignments were outstanding. He always answers your questions and makes sure you really get it and independently reach a conclusion. Gerard was Gerard. Consistent, concise, clear. Really made OPAMPS easy to understand when it started to become difficult. Sad to hear this might be his last year of teaching 101, but with William taking over, I’m sure first years will find it a quality course indeed.
It is quite a divisive course but as long as you do the mcqs, assignments without getting the answers from your mates, you should do well in this course.

I ended up not going to lectures when Udaya was teaching and instead just tried to teach myself with the coursebook which was hard because it didnt really make sense in some topics. Studying for exams was really hard and I dont think OPAMPs were taught very well. The assignments were really good for learning things though.
Goodluck :/

ELECTENG 101.Name: Anonymous
Content: Boring, didn't show up to lectures but Udaya was a sweetie

ELECTENG 101.Name: Anonymous
Content: Just re-watch the lectures. It's derivation heavy, and most questions are designed so that you start from the first principle. If you rely on past papers, you are not gonna do well.
Tips: (applies to CHEMMAT 121 too btw)
- your revision should be based on rewatching lectures and understanding all the derivations.
- William purposefully shows everything from the first principle. Just understand it. it will come in handy
- the practice questions booklet. There are >100 questions, and they are all useful. Just do them all.
- Piazza. Ask everything you feel unsure about.
- do around 2 years worth of past papers. This is so that you can be used to the style of the questions, and common tricks he puts in.
- each week there's an assignment (online) that uses circuit program. Sometimes it marks things incorrectly. Tell the lecturer. they are happy to check and mark up your grade
now comments on lecturers:

- ignore william for the first 5 lectures up to current/voltage source. you may not understand why he goes at length talking about voltages and stuff. then try understand the 6th lecture. you will find that you can't understand him. go rewatch 5 lectures. you can now see why he waffled for a while. they are important. in fact, everything in his lectures is important. it's hard to appreciate it at first when he rambles on and on about SMART response tech etc. but it's one of those things that click in in the big picture
- he's boring though, but quite clearly enthusiastic. idk. i liked him!

- op-amp and other random stuffs are taught by bill. op-amp is very poorly explained. but you are gonna have to understand how all the equations were derived, because that's like 1/3 of the exam. make sure you learn all of them through piazza and YOUTUBE. the other fluffs are very generic, they won't really come up. (FET switch and stuff). what you can't understand from the first principle doesn't come out in tests/exam. so you can safely ignore them. you aren't gonna need to rote-learn anything either. just ignore all the stats.

The tests and exams are really hard in the sense that you need to know how to apply the content in unfamiliar situations. Which means that rote learning is useless for this course. Apparently the exams get scaled really hard so don't cry when you open the exam paper. Also, I ran out of time for the exam paper and left 2 pages blank.

COMPSYS 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course was revamped for 2017, especially the microcontrollers section. Split into two parts: Logic gates to register design taught by Kevin Wang and microcontrollers taught by Bill Collis.

Course was alright. Both lecturers were good, though the content could get a bit boring at times. They're both very approchable and responsive to questions post-lectures, which is really nice. Probably the most relevant course for compsys students this semester, along with electeng 210. If you enjoy designing digital circuits to solve a variety of problems, this course is for you. This course does move a bit slowly though, but it seems to be because of backlash over complaints from previous years. Not as much emphasis on VDHL or C coding in the exams, which is instead the focus of the labs and assignments.

Has a crappy writing assignment at the beginning though, which you won't be prepped a whole lot for. Thankfully it's not worth much but it was still a pain. Very forgettable too so I don't even see the point of having done it.

COMPSYS 201.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course was ok, I didn't go to any of Kevin's lectures because they were fucking BORING - when he turned those lights off, I just fell asleep.
Bill's lectures were great and everything was well explained. Assignments are easy, content is easy, Andrew Chen is a god on piazza, if you study well enough the test/exams are easy as well.

COMPSYS 201.Name: KuriGohan and Kamehameha
Content: The lectures are sleep-inducing and the last half of this paper will be challenging for those who have little to no computer hardware knowledge. I highly recommend referring Vahid's textbook for the first two sections of this course. It's easy to get lost in the third section, as the lecturer expects a certain base of knowledge that many of you won't have. I knew a few people who didn't finish the MST. The exam was reasonably challenging, although one of the lecturers pretty much told us what would be in his section. You'll need to use google-fu to teach yourself the concepts if you want a good grade, but our grades were significantly scaled up anyway, so it's possible for someone even with no prior knowledge to get into A / A+ territory. Additionally, the lecturers are friendly and more than happy to help you during their office hours. What is taught in this course is much better learned through practical application, which you'll experience in ELECTENG 209.
