ENGGEN 150.Name: Anonymous
Content: I just finished this course and I have nothing better to do with my break so this is going to be a pretty comprehensive review.

First I'll cover workload/difficulty. This course is for conjoint students and combines ENGGEN 121 and ENGSCI 111. Because of this, all the content is covered a lot quicker. In this course, you have four lectures per week (two on 121 content, two for 111 content) plus a clinic session. A clinic is basically where you can sit in a common study space and work on problems while the lecturer wanders around in case you have questions or anything. I only went to one of these because the study spaces are pretty crowded and also because I felt weird working on problems in such a 'public' place (idk why). These basically stopped around halfway through the semester though because the turnout was too low. If you were to take the 121 and 111 courses separately, you would have 3 lectures per week for each plus tutorial(s) (not sure how many tutorials). A tutorial is similar to a clinic except it is smaller and they are kind of 'more compulsory' and a bit more structured. Plus a tutor (not the lecturer) takes them. I was quite worried about whether or not I would be able to keep up with the accelerated pace but it is not too bad. They ease you in gently and the first week or two is pretty much just refreshing your memory of high school physics and math. BEWARE though: uni goes from 0-100 real quick and you really, really need to stay on top of things or you can fall behind very quickly. This advice comes from experience. I personally found the mathematics or 111 part of the course decent/manageable. As someone mentioned already, vectors and matrices may be a bit tricky if you haven't encountered them before but I had done Cambridge so I found it all right. Also, the Practice Problems coursebook is really really helpful. They have problems (and, even better, solutions!) organised by topic and they are usually of similar difficulty to what you would be expected to do in assessments. I would recommend you complete the appropriate section of this coursebook as you cover them in lectures, just to practise and understand the concept. Now, where everything went to custard for me was the mechanics or 121 stuff. It starts off okay but then I kind of stopped doing the practice problems at the end of each section because I got it when the lecturer explained the examples, plus motivation kind of dropped off, plus I had work from courses as well etc etc. DO NOT DO THIS! Keep up with the content! I was left trying to catch up on like four weeks worth of stuff the week before the final exam. Needless to say, this did not go too well. The statics section of mechanics is easier than dynamics for most people (including me) because it is the first section taught and also everything pretty much just adds to zero. Dynamics is a step up from the NCEA Level 3 Physics Mechanics topic. So, overall, while it is an accelerated course, I think it is manageable provided you keep up with the content as it's being taught. Also, I found the 111 stuff easier than the 121 stuff. I did occasionally regret choosing a conjoint program and having to take the combined course but looking back on it now, I'm not sure if I would have done (much) better in the two separate courses. I guess we'll see once exam results come out.

Okay, next I'll talk a bit about the lecturers. For the 111 content, we had David Dempsey and Colin Simpson. Colin was a good, really approachable lecturer. David was outstanding and personally my favourite lecturer of the course and possibly the whole semester. David has lecture breaks where he asks trivia questions and awards chocolate for the person with the right answer (possible motivation to attend lectures?). This was great for obvious reasons. I found that both of them explained things well. For the 121 content we had Jason for statics and Karl for dynamics. Jason does have a kind of straightforward, sometimes condescending teaching style which some people seemed to like but which I personally did not enjoy. I didn't find him very approachable but I appreciate that he came in a bit earlier to answer questions we might have. A lot of other students made use of this. Karl used a flipped lecture method where basically he posted videos for us to watch before the timetabled lecture (these lectures explained the concepts) and then during the lecture, he would go through relevant examples. This was a pretty good idea especially given the time constraints of this course but of course sometimes myself and others would forget to watch the videos beforehand. Karl was very approachable. Overall, good to average lecturing with one stand-out. Also, you should have access to the lecture recordings from the separate 111 and 121 course so it might be helpful watch those if you want more explanation or prefer a different lecturer's teaching style.

I guess the last part to cover is the assessment. The exam at the end of semester makes up the bulk of your grade and is weighted at 60% so it's pretty important you prepare well for this. Half the exam is mathematics and half is mechanics. I was confident with the mathematics part of it but kind of shaky on the other half. I got the general feeling most people felt they did stronger in the mathematics, just because of the nature of the mechanics questions this semester. Throughout the semester, you also have a statics test worth 10%, a dynamics test worth 10%. and two mathematics tests worth 7% each. Because these tests are smaller, there's less pressure and I found them manageable. The remaining 6% comes from 9 mathematics assignments. At the end of each module, you get an assignment sheet, answer the questions, and then submit your answers through the online quiz. Someone else noted that because you only give your final answers in the quiz, there's little leeway and you don't get marks for working. So, I guess check your work and answers before submitting the assignment. You aren't allowed calculators during the maths tests so try not to verify basic arithmetic with it. For mechanics, you are allowed approved, restricted calculators.

Whew, finally made it! I hope you found that helpful (hopefully not too overwhelming or confusing). One random thing I liked about this course is the small cohort  that take it. Someone else talked about this on this page already and I would definitely have to agree. It will probably be your smallest class and it's a nice break from those other lectures filled with hundreds of other people.
Good luck and enjoy the ride :)

ENGGEN 303.Name: Anonymous
Content: 20% of your final mark for "participation" (read: attendance, just renamed so they can get away with it) is a joke. Rob is a knob, he doesn't really care and I don't really give a damn about his opinions which aren't relevant to the course. Fix those two things and you'd have 5 stars for enjoyment and overall. The lectures themselves are alright, but a little slow and the attendance makes it stupid. Make the lectures more engaging by fixing the problem (slow, not much content each time, some average lecturers), ditch attendance, and you'd get 4 stars or more for lecture quality. I do like quizzes in class for helping engagement, but they should be there for being interesting, not just a means for registering attendance. They had an awesome guest lecturer who did the 2012 London Olympics construction, he now works at UoA I believe - get him to take over from Rob and do more stuff, he's good.

Tutorials were okay, generally good tutors from what I've heard from other students. I had Jim, who's awesome. Systems week was fun, just make sure your lazy team members don't let it all fall apart and screw up the content you have prepared.

Reflection on Learnings are a bit pointless. I think they're good for students to do to recap what they've learned (and you'll find you learn a lot more when you have to write about it), but I don't think they should be assessed and graded. Encourage students to write them, don't force them.

Final marks can be redistrubuted. Ditch attendance and RoLs, and maybe put those marks more into the individual assignments, and also the tutorial group assignments (which are currently worth a whopping 0%).

ENGSCI 753.Name: Anonymous
Content: I found this course super interesting and challenging.
In 2018 it was taught by:

- Sammuel Rosset (FEM 1) who was a good lecturer although he seemed to only understand the content at a surface level (I think he was thrown in to teaching a few weeks prior because Keri Moyle was away this year). Non the less did a good job.

- Harvey Ho (FEM 2) who taught Streamline Upwind Galerkin-Petro FEM and explicit and implicit time stepping methods. He is a little hard to understand because he has a strong accent but the notes are full if you are prepared to work through the complex derivations.
- Justin Fernadez (Discrete element method) - this part of the course was super easy in the exam and difficult in the course work but everyone got a really good mark so IDK.
This course had:

- Really hard c++ coding assignments (work in groups or you won't do well) that were really rewarding when completed because we essentially built a FEM solver from the ground up. When I say work in groups I mean help each other, it should go both ways.

- Exam was pretty easy because they asked the same questions as previous years. I got an A+ with just 5 days of dedicated study before the exam (and doing the assignments/keeping up with the course through out (sorta)).
I recommend this course to the Engsci's that don't want to do all OR papers, have an interest in mechanical engineering, enjoyed Computational Techniques 2 and aren't afraid of coding.
Good luck!

Let's start of with Tony. In 2019 Tony taught us decision making under uncertainty. DMUU is a interesting topic and the notes are well organised and the content is reasonably understandable. The only issue is that Tony likes to destroy us any chance he gets, so his section of the exam is always super unpredictable and tricky. The assignment was alg

Heuristics was taught by Andrew Mason and was in my opinion the best taught. The notes are super helpful and Andrew is an excellent lecturer (even though he can be a bit condescending at times). The assignment was difficult and long but rewarding. His exam section is always pretty similar but parts of it can be pretty tricky.

And don't get me started on dynamic programming. By far the most difficult topic I've had to drag myself through so far. I find it very hard to wrap my head around even the basic examples, and I feel it wasn't as well-taught as it could have been. Almost everyone this year thought they were going to get rolled by this exam. Thankfully it wasn't the worst in the world, but it definitely could have been.
So overall, beware of this course. Lots of content and it's tricky. But it can be done with enough effort

ENGSCI 760.Name: Anonymous
Content: A bit too much content

ENGSCI 233.Name: Anonymous
Content: CS: Jim literally put me to sleep every lecture. Stopped attending by week 2. Labs 3 and 4 didn't relate to content taught, which was fine, just not expected.
CT: Went once, never came back. Google was more useful than Jupyterhub.
Labs are temperamental - for some, these take half the week. I sat down Sunday nights and cracked it in about 5-6 hours. Monday night was used for debugging if needed.
Exam: Jim's section is the same every year. Absolutely no reason to get anything below 50%.

The CT lecturer(s? not 100% sure I never attended) changed this year so the exam was a lot easier than I thought it would be. Went in thinking it was the one I was least prepared for, in the end it was my best mark lol.

Nothing "fun and enjoyable" about this course - but there is the satisfaction when you finish a lab and everything works, outputs a nice diagram. And a little bit maybe in the group labs for CS, if you got a good group that did stuff. Which wasn't me. I basically wrote half the code and one other person wrote the other, leaving three people who did nothing.
Lecture quality three stars because I have heard people say they loved the CT section, average that out with a 1 for Jim.

ENGSCI 233.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course covers Computer Systems (CS) first and then Computational Techniques (CT).
Computer Systems:

This section of the course was relatively easy, it was very similar to what was covered in ELECTENG 101 with a bit more of a focus on how information is stored in a computer. Sections included Information Representation in Computers, Digital Logic Gates, Synchronous Circuits and Hardware Software Interface. I enjoyed this course some what but it wasn't really that interesting at first as the lecturer didnt really excite my interest in the subject very much. Luckily he wasn't our only lecturer and the course soon became much more interesting and challenging. Overall it was an alright course.
Computational Techniques:

This section of the course was very interesting and very challenging and similar to ENGSCI 111 and ENGGEN 131 except much much harder. Every week there is a coding assignment that takes on average about 8 hours to do it well. This created a huge amount of work and sucked up most of the time I would have spent actually studying the lecture content. This is a very hard course, which is to be expected as it is a course that is only taken by Engsci and Biomedical students. The lecturer for this part of the course was entertaining and interesting but wasnt afraid to set a really heavy work load and joked about finding joy in making us suffer. The sections included Floating Point Arithmetic, Sorting Algorithms, Linear Equations (LU factorisations and such), Interpolation (see Lagrange Interpolation on Wikipedia if you want to see the kind of things that were studied), Numerical and Analytic Integration and Numerical ODE's.
Overall it is a hard but very interesting course that should be taken if you like coding in C and Matlab, a lot of very tough maths, logic, computer architecture and computer science.

ENGSCI 233.Name: Anonymous
Content: A high quality well structured course

I thoroughly enjoyed this course. I think things changed this year, and the content and labs went together really well. I learned so much and the weekly labs being worth marks meant everyone was very focused on this course which was really good.
All of the lecturers were really good and very engaging!

ENGSCI 233.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course is fucking hard. The ratio of time spent on this course to the time spent on all my other courses combined is very large. The labs are so ridiculously draining - it took me 4 days to complete each one, and they come back to haunt you every week. I struggled so much with this course - i still ended up with a good grade but the amount of time spent slaving was not worth
Lecturers are great - love David and Colin to death. Jim is an okay lecturer but his part of the course is easy (thank the lord above for his section of the exam <333333333).
But yeah, prepare yourself because this course is soul destroying

ENGSCI 233.Name: Anonymous
Content: My 2018 experience generally agrees with what the July 25 2017 reviewer wrote. A few things I want to say tho:

-Nobody's mentioned this yet but two of your CS labs will be on a group project where you use MATLAB to instruct a Lego Mindstorm robot to maneuver around a little obstacle course using its different sensors. While it takes a lot of time to make it work and the robots can be stubborn sometimes, it's really cool to see all the different groups testing their robots and the different approaches people took to the problem.

-I found the weekly CT coding labs usually took around 10 hours to complete. I would definitely not recommend starting on the due date because you're pretty likely to need to debug which can take an unpredictable amount of time.
-Completing each CT lab was really satisfying and I found them to be fun little coding projects to learn Python (and refresh your MATLAB and C skills).
-A lot of the CT stuff for the exam had to be self taught as David didn't really teach it in class.
-Overall, I reckon this was my favourite course of semester 1, if not the whole year

ENGSCI 233.Name: Jeremy Cheung
Content: Mrs.Dempsey is insanely attractive.

ENGSCI 233.Name: Samuel Mei
Content: This is my 5th time doing this course.

ENGSCI 233.Name: Anonymous
Content: I'd rather have an exam rather than getting absolutely annihilated by the endless fuckload of labs

ENGSCI 233.Name: Anonymous
Content: Overall structure of course is so horrible. I was taking this when lockdown happened. It is also the first year where we do not have exams which is good right...?

Holy Shit fuck no. Quizzes are at the start of every week so you have to watch them before Monday PLUS MM2 Lectures and Quizzes BONUS if you do Biosci107 for biomed people who have to watch 4 lectures (which covers a content of 3 lectures) every week AND a quizz or a lab.

That is fine until you have lectures which basically tell you a concept and you are like cool okay, doable and then in the lab they make it ultra fking hard, they literally say theres an ocean full of sharks, we just taught you how to swim in theory, good luck and they DONT PUSH YOU BUT THROW YOU OFF THE CLIFF. LIKE WTF, their lab session is on Wednesday morning you have no spare time to read the mannual instructions due to the staggering amount of shit you have to do for small quizzes and they only help you on the day the lab is released after that you get 0 help maybe from piazza where half of it useless. I had no time to read most of the lab instructions because I was too tired from the other courses because the content is hitting me like a truck or just trying to finish the previous lab BECAUSE ITS SO DAMN FKING HARD.

One of the labs was PLU factorisation, David gave us a video from the previous years, where he screwed up and he was like hmmm idk what I am doing and proceeds to carry on like nothing happened. So we got 0 information on what we are meant to do. OMG and cloning gits and installing conda 233, do not get me started on that shit, it is tilting asf. My computer could not clone idk why I asked the lecturers and they were like well too bad i guess gotta toughen up.. Dude you are one fking emotionless robot. The labs take FOREVER unless you are gifted at coding they also tell you to learn new shit on stack overflow in the lab instructions. Did I mention that you get marked on efficiency as well although it is not on the rubic. -_- Oh yeah and you have at least an extra assignment from one of your courses or a test every fking week. HECK I had 3 tests in one week. My daily was 3 quizzes, 1 normal lab, THIS FKING LAB and a staggering 16 lectures to watch + INSERT ASSIGNMENT OR TEST. I had to sacrifice labs to do well in the other test unless I had to consume 20 red bulls. But then BIOSCI was like during this pandemic the labs are too easy you know what we are going to make it harder. My lyfe crumbled as I read that e-mail...

David is an absolute troll and heartless fker. Engineering is notorious for using weird english and although he is white, my dear god. I could not understand what 2 of the questions meant in a test on his section. I asked him and he said its up to you, 'We assess your interpretation.' HA cool I am literally reading a foreign language here but ok I will give it my best shot, do you mean this? Then they are like well it did not match with our interpretation and they cuck you, they do not have the brains to even consider how you interpreted it. Oh yeah and he forgot that one of the lecture recordings he uploaded was a duplicate. So when I did the quiz and I saw new stuff, I did not know what to do. He ONLY noticed it until Monday morning where he re-uploaded a new lecture recording. An absolute dick. Oh yeah for the project you barely get 2 weeks... Like wtf I need a break and engsci233 is like, NOP get used to it engineer. You get no life, we are training you to become a workaholic.
Honestly my advice is to pass this course, it is not worth the time and effort for the marks you get.

I actually prayed that David would get corona and die painfully so many times. All in all, if you want to do well in this course be prepared to die or sacrifice your other courses. OR be a social freak and become friends with the gods who sit in the front of the class (who normally do not help) and pray that you get some help, I mean smart guys (sorry but most of the girls does not even look close to girls) literally would not help you unless you are a chick (LOL).

This course is poorly structured, poorly taught, harsh asf markings and little to no help. Just pray and hope you get 2/6 in every lab at least and pass the tests so you have some leeway to ditch certain labs when you need it. Send my regards to this arrogant asf course co-ordinator that I would slit his throat if I see him. I pray you survive through this course comrade and I will see you in other courses.

ENGSCI 255.Name: Anonymous
Content: The post on 23/11/17 pretended to be me.

It is true that I found this the easiest course in the semester. The facts in that review are also correct. However it would be a disservice to call this course a "joke", as hundreds of hours have been put into the course both by lecturers and students. From my understanding it (may) be getting restructured, and is also going to be limited to sem 1 (up till 2017 we had it in both semesters).

On the whole this course was good, and some of it is actually taught in ENGSCI 311 (not 314, which is mm3 for engsci students). Shows how applicable it is I guess. Develops excel number crunching skills (204 is actually a joke). Many summer internships have something similar to 255 projects (like I am currently doing).
As long as you understand what's happening in class (not too hard of an ask at all),  you should be able to ace test and exam with some study.

ENGSCI 255.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course is well thought out and very interesting. For me it was by far the most interesting 2nd year engsci course. The project does make everything harder and be prepared to basically do your report entirely in the final 2 days but other than thats its alg. also prepare all the engsci averages to be 95% but youre prob used to that already

ENGSCI 255.Name: Anonymous
Content: Course is pretty enjoyable and interesting. While most found it to be relatively easy, its definitely not a free A+ (especially because of Geoff's section on Queuing and Simulation).

Also, please look at the Stats 255 reviews too as this course is exactly the same except 10% of the exam grade is moved to an extension section for the engsci students. The extension section consists of two 3% assignments and a 4% test covering data analytics topics learnt in a few lectures. The assignments mostly involved coding in R, using various techniques such as random forests, classification trees, clustering, etc. Test was kinda weird cause it was the first time having one and we weren't given any practice questions or tests to let us know what to expect. The extension content was pretty interesting and apparently may find its way into the main course in 2019.

ENGSCI 255.Name: Anonymous
Content: Good course, good lecturers, not too challenging.
I found this course interesting, but not too draining which was nice in comparison to other papers at the time.
The first section is the best in my opinion - great lecturing from Kevin. However, the others are also really interesting, I think just less satisfying/clear topics.
The test is all good - just do some study and you'll be great. Exam also fine with a bit of study. The regular assignments really help to prepare you for these.

ENGSCI 255.Name: Downward
Content: Oi nah give us an 18 page assignment that's a good idea.
Shit course, Data Visualization is gay as fuck too give us some real Maths

ENGSCI 255.Name: Anonymous
Content: this course is a joke cause you take it with the stats people
the mode is A+ in engsci
Average is high A
I learnt the last third of the course in 5 hours

ENGSCI 263.Name: Anonymous
Content: By far the hardest course in 2nd semester, watch out and manage your time well.

The design projects really sucked my soul out lol. When they say they wanted 20 hours on project A, they showed us the best looking one from last year. Of course everyone now had to beat it (since we are engsci) and the whole thing turned into a giant pissing match up at 70. As soon as some group implemented a new feature, every other group had it too by the next day. Some people spent 50-100 hours on this.
Project B was 2 days after engsci255 project report, so everyone doing 255 had a fun time those two days (not a problem for 2018 onwards because they are restricting 255 to sem 1).
The CM section was by far the most interesting content we learnt the whole year, and my favourite. Loved it.
Exam was harder than expected, needed 1 more mark for A+ :'(
As with 233, average out the lecture quality 1 for Jim and 5 for everyone else (this year John, David and Rosalind).

ENGSCI 263.Name: Anonymous
Content: This was a great course. I believe that this (as well as many other part 2 engsci papers) were restructured this year - and it seems to have really helped. The content was all really engaging - all the lectures were good, and the lecturers seemed really invested in the course which was nice (Kevin and David).

We had 2 projects - one CM and one OR. The first was an 8 week CM project where there were a range of projects, with 2-3 groups doing each. This project involved a peer review, a written proposal, coded model, and presentation as the group assessment (worth around 15% total). It also had a 12% individual report component. Splitting the group project up into an individual and group section was really good, and I think it may have helped with group participation. Second project was much the same, except a smaller time frame and no presentation. Both projects were really well planned and involved a lot of python programming. I probably spent around 25-30 hours on the first and 15-20 on the second.
There are also fortnightly (ish) labs which add up to 16% of the final grade. This is quite a lot and these labs do take a bit of time. Also some of them have attendance marks.

Exam was good - nothing too new, but also got us to apply everything we'd learned. It didn't feel too much like a collection of random facts, but this course is a little bitsy at times. Exam is 40% though and so all good with some study.
In short : Great course, great teaching, great projects!

ENGSCI 263.Name: Anonymous
Content: Design section:

Project A is a 9 week group project where you use VBA to design a platform for customising a mechanical device eg a trebuchet, bike, helicopter, etc. They recommend each group member puts in 20 hours into the project for 100 hours per group but most groups went significantly over this amount (I heard one guy put in 100 hours!). Definitely a solid learning experience that requires good time management throughout the semester to avoid spending your entire mid sem break in 70. Project B involved using SolidWorks to model your Project A device and VBA to change your SolidWorks parts. Marking of the reports was extremely lenient so just make sure to have all the sections they ask for eg discussion of sample results. Pretty cool to see the interaction between CAD and code too.
Modelling section:

This has a CM subsection taught by Peng and a subsection on Uncertainty and Calibration of models taught by David. The CM section was pretty much rote-learning derivations - I found this section extremely boring and tedious. It was assessed by literally just copying out derivations you had done in class. Uncertainty and Calibration was interesting and a lot of it was common sense stats stuff. It had non-graded labs associated with it, but the stuff you learnt in it came up in the exam so I'd recommend to actually complete them throughout the semester when you can get easily get help.

Overall, this course had by far the heaviest workload and it felt like two whole courses in one. Fortunately, everyone does the low workload paper ENGGEN 204 in the same semester which means its manageable. Despite the amount of time investment required for this course, it was pretty satisfying to complete the projects and have something cool to show for all your effort, making this course many people's favourite.

ENGSCI 263.Name: Same guy from 20/12/17
Content: Just thought I'd mention I'm literally doing a 263 project A at my summer internship lmao

ENGSCI 263.Name: Anonymous
Content: lol our exam buckingham pi q is 3%. same thing in civil exam is 11%

ENGSCI 331.Name: Anonymous
Content: Easiest ENGSCI paper in part 3 imo.
Continuation of 233 CT. In 2018, topics covered were:
Databases - a bit dry but useful knowledge. Lab in Access. SQL.

ODEs - useful as always. Lab was in python, with a competitive bit (meaning only one person could conceivably get 100%; it's only like 10% of the assignment mark though. And quite easy to do well in it too)
Non linear equations - root finding methods. Pretty easy (labs were in MATLAB so that made it easy too).
Finite differences - hardest lab imo, python. Hard to visualize what you're doing, came at THAT time during the semester (363 wind turbine, other papers' assignments, etc.)
Eigenproblems - lab was good difficulty, you learn pretty much all the eigen content for the exam from doing the lab.
Univariate minimization - very easy once you understand the concepts.

ENGSCI 343.Name: Anonymous
Content: This course is very lecturer dependent, I feel.
John Cater fluids in 2017 was gg, John Cater solids in 2018 was gg

Stupid fluids assignment this year, canvas quiz out of 18 marks for 7.5% . One of the 4 mark questions is therefore worth 1.7% of the entire course, which one little working error screws you out of (canvas quiz is all or nothing).
They cut out half of fluids this year, to "gain a deeper understanding".

ENGSCI 343.Name: Anonymous
Content: Piaras was pretty good. David Dempsey doing fluids was fantastic. Pretty hard content but the lecturers (David especially) explained things well

ENGSCI 343.Name: Anonymous
Content: Solid Mechanics is fine, Piaras is a great lecturer and gives you the best study guides. Fluid mechanics on the other hand is quite difficult and the lecture notes are missing a lot of definitions and examples.

ENGSCI 343.Name: Anonymous
Content: Piaras stuff is allgood. Continuum mechanics isnt too bad. Jim's stuff on Fluid Mechanics is recked, no examples or anything either.

ENGSCI 355.Name: Anonymous
Content: Very easy course and good lecturers helped me just sneak into the deans list haha

ENGSCI 391.Name: Anonymous
Content: ENGSCI 391 was taught by two lecturers this year: Caroline Jagtenberg and Golbon Zakeri; Caroline was new and, as such, sometimes difficult to follow because of her lack of familiarity with our baseline understanding of the required mathematical notation. Golbon was more familiar with what we could or could not parse with respect to notation, and was relatively easier to learn from. Both lecturers were reliant on slides and I felt that, because of this, some of the content vital to answering exam/test questions felt omitted or very opaque/obscure, especially for those who entered indirectly from engineering and science (i.e. those not from Engineering Science or who had not taken ENGSCI 255/STATS 255).

Linear programming (revised and dual simplex method) dominated most of the course, and was taught jointly by Caroline in Weeks 1–4 and Golbon to completion. Probably the hardest section to begin from, especially if the concept of linear programming is new to one. However, the entry requirements assume you have taken at least a first-year linear algebra course, so generalising linear programs to matrices and vectors should be easy to catch on to with practice.
Networks (network simplex method) was second and wholly taught by Golbon. Quite a good section and an intuitive progression from the revised simplex method, which was great.

The final module, integer programming, was shoehorned in at the last minute, and taught alongside pre-written notes. Golbon taught this section as well, taking over from Andrew Mason. Understanding this section was very contingent on whether or not you could make the lectures, as lecture recordings did tend to be uploaded a week after.

All sections were generally very temperamental and reliant on sticking it out until the end, as you were drip-fed knowledge and made to think. Draw your own conclusions as to whether or not this is good pedagogy. However, I felt there needs to be more support in the form of past test and exam answers that would give a clearer picture of the required approaches to assessment, and that lectures didn't feel so rote-taught. Someone like Kevin Jia springs to mind as someone who is a wonderful applied mathematics teacher (see ENGSCI 211).

Programming assignments in MATLAB (one on linear programming and the other on networks) were carried through year-by-year with same questions, so one might call into question the integrity of internal assessment in the course and dodgy mean scores. Tests were hastily done, and one test (Test 2) had misprints/omissions; very disorganised.
Overall, a sometimes disjointed mixed bag – with a few notable highlights.

ENGSCI 391.Name: Anonymous
Content: Zakeri lectures well. Mason was fine.
Simplex section of the course is good, if a bit slow. Network section is good, Integer Programming was too easy I feel (could even plop this section into 255).
Assignments were fine. Exam was fine. Overall a good course even if I found it boring (CM all the way!)

ENGSCI 391.Name: Anonymous
Content: As a fourth year student, I want everyone to know before taking this course that this course is absolutely fundamental to any OR course you take further. Make sure you really pay attention to how RSM works because it really is a baseline for all OR courses to follow!

ENGSCI 391.Name: Anonymous
Content: Not overtly difficult, but does require a fair amount of prior knowledge to complete this course to a high standard. Simply meeting the entry requirements will require some background reading, although this should be okay if your linear algebra skills and understanding of notation in-class is sufficient. Assignments need to be more fair, especially as the questions each year thus far have come from 2013's cohort (dodgy!) and can worked on between students from all years. Plussage is offered in this course, which is nice, but the tests were way too disorganised to rely on for marks. Insufficient time as well. Course needs some fundamental improvement, but Golbon is generally a good lecturer. Simplex module is dominant and really is fundamental to the course. Networks and integer programming expand upon the simplex method (revised simplex method).
In conclusion, ehhh.

ENGSCI 391.Name: Anonymous
Content: Golbon should do ASMR

MECHENG 712.Name: Anonymous
Content: Poorly taught and structured. Interesting content but very abstract and difficult to grasp. You'll end up ignoring this all year round then cramming and memorizing concepts you don't actually understand for the exam.

MECHENG 712.Name: Anonymous
Content: The one paper I wanted to take since coming to uni. Lol what a joke. I learnt ass about physics, whole first third of the course was a repeat of a paper I did in 3rd year.
Did CFD project in one day and still did better than the mean cause it was taught so badly (I did it last year too). People understood nothing about why they were doing what they were doing.
Last third can be learnt from a book, not sure why they teach it in class.

I was cramming for my other exams which you can actually study for so I basically learnt 2/3 of the course in about 12 hours, hence the bad mark. Like this course just involves memorising methods of solution and penalises you for the rest of the question if you get a single number wrong.

MECHENG 712.Name: Anonymous
Content: Overall, I really enjoyed AeroHydro as someone keen on aviation. Theory is really interesting and projects are enjoyable. However the concepts and diravations are extremely hard. This is a paper where cramming for the exam is not going to work well. I learnt a lot in this course and enjoyed the projects but be prepared for a GPA hit.

MECHENG 712.Name: Anonymous
Content: content wise it is hard. But the theory is really interesting. I really enjoyed the topic.

MECHENG 712.Name: Anonymous
Content: regardless of what people say this is an easy paper. the derivations arent too bad if you're good at math. and at the end of the day if the whole class does badly cause the content is difficult it'll be scaled accordingly thus your gpa wont take a hit

MECHENG 713.Name: Anonymous
Content: There wasn't anything interesting about this course and don't be tempted by the name 'energy tech' the course is mostly about boiling, condensation, mass transfer and transient heat transfer. Apart from the mass transfer section the note's are not very helpful unless you like the style where you go to lectures and fill in the missing gaps like a 5 year old.

MECHENG 713.Name: Anonymous
Content: A good course covering heat and mass transfer and energy cycles. Raj’s mass transfer lectures could get rather dry, but as always Stuart and Al were entertaining. Different styles of notes; Stuart makes you write parts of it down (though did upload a complete version online too, if you’ve done four years of engineering and forgotten how to use a pen after all the computers), the others just give you stuff to read, but either way the notes tell you just what you need to know. The assignments are very doable, and the exam, while open book, does demand a good grasp of just what you need to do, particularly when it comes to the energy cycles.

MECHENG 722.Name: Anonymous
Content: Overall I actually really enjoyed the course and found the content pretty interesting. Both Brian and Lihua are very knowledgeable and definitely know their content. Brian is easy to listen to and is a pretty good lecturer but his notes are quite brief so are harder to learn from when studying for exams. In comparison to 2nd year I think Lihua has definitely improved his English and in my opinion if you focus in the lectures he isnt as bad as everyone makes him out to be and whatever he lacks in lecturing abilities he makes up for in his notes which are written out in full with accompanying examples.

MECHENG 722.Name: Anonymous
Content: Lihua is a crap lecturer, I dont know how he got the job to be honest. I liked vibrations in 3rd year but this course is completely theoretical and very boring. Glad if I can save one person from taking this course.

MECHENG 724.Name: KARL STOL IS A LAD
Content: This course is made do able only cause its taught by karl. karl is a legend, one of the best lecturers in the mech department if not the whole university

MECHENG 724.Name: Anonymous
Content: Karl is a great lecturer and makes resources available to help you along, Peter not so much and is a bit hard to understand. The content is quite difficult, but has interesting applications. No regrets.

MECHENG 726.Name: Anonymous
Content: Some very interesting content, about human hearing and perception. Very comprehensive detail of anyone considering going into the field and covers heaps of relevant stuff you might never bother to learn otherwise even in working in the area.
Was a bit boring at times and Dodd isn't going to be everyones favourite lecturer

MECHENG 211.Name: Anonymous
Content: Boring course. Tests you more on unit conversions and typing into a calculator than actual content.
Thermodynamics is learning how to read and extract data from tables, and translating from English into maths.
Fluid dynamics is learning how to read the question and select a formula.
Heat transfer is... I don't know cause I learnt the entire section in about 5 hours (thought I had another day). Helps the first two weeks were covered in 2 lectures in engsci263.
Tbh easy A+ if I studied for the first test, or learnt heat transfer lol.

MECHENG 211.Name: Michael Eo
Content: piss easy

MECHENG 211.Name: Anonymous
Content: Sharma is cool,...but Stuart is not capable to explain the phenomena at all. Quite a bad lecturer, it's so sad........

MECHENG 211.Name: Anonymous
Content: Like the others have said this is a pretty boring course. Richard seems like he really doesn't want to be there. Assessment consists of reading values from a table and putting them into your calculator. Very little emphasis on understanding, instead you're just instructed which dimensionally inconsistent equation to use. The one interesting bit was on heat dissipation from fins for which the derivation was skipped over as quickly as possible. I will say studying for this course is just a matter of cranking through past exams.
If you're engsci and wanting to take this as an elective I would recommend against it. You learn most of this in a lot more detail in 263 and there are far more interesting/useful courses out there.
If you're mechanical/mechatronics then I hope you like steam tables.

MECHENG 211.Name: ThermoGod
Content: This course was competing with Dynamics (MechEng 222) for the hardest paper for Mech Part 2 Sem 2. There were 3 different sections, 2 tests which were difficult asf, labs were fairly simple, and the exam was also hard. Most of my notes were torn apart due to the water from my tears falling down on it. I recommend getting the textbook as they have glossy pages and can withstand 1-2 teardrops. Also, watch youtube videos about the topic as the lecturers aren't the most reliable in terms of delivering the content. No coursebook.

MECHENG 211.Name: Anonymous
Content: A pretty hard course. It involves a lot of memorising. The lecturers are pretty nice though, however most of the notes are a literal copy and paste from the the recommenced text book. I highly suggest that you buy it as it will make your life so much easier.

MECHENG 211.Name: Anonymous
Content: Stuart is a waste of time,...

MECHENG 222.Name: Anonymous

No idea how on earth he became qualified to be a lecturer when the job depends entirely on communication.. In english.. Completely ruins the course in my opinion, makes it very hard to learn.

MECHENG 222.Name: Anonymous
Content: I love Lihua and Hazim so much, even the tutors were amazing! The Project for the first part was fairly given in terms of content and time but the Simulink assignment was worth only 5% and it has the same amount of work as the project. Tests were fairly made as well in terms of difficulty but the exam was a step up and if you want to get a good grade then you have to keep up with the amount of content in this course and of course keep up with MechEng 211 (Thermofluids) since Thermofluids have 1.5x more content than Dynamics.

MECHENG 222.Name: Anonymous
Content: Really good course, with really passionate lecturers

MECHENG 222.Name: Anonymous
Content: A pretty hard course. The coursework itself isn't too bad except for an assignment near the end of the semester which was worth way to little imo when compared to the amount of work needed. Well structured notes however at times it can be kinda overwhelming. This isn't a paper you can just ignore and cram for, you need to put the work in as a lot of the problems are heavily logic based. You need to think carefully about how you attempt the problem, it is very easy to make simple mistakes. First lecturer accent made the first half of the material harder than it needed to be, but the material itself isnt hard.

MECHENG 222.Name: Anonymous
Content: First lecturer looks like a panda, cant teach. Hazim should teach the whole course

MECHENG 222.Name: Anonymous
Content: First lecturer was terrible.  Second lecturer was fantastic.  Great coursebook is provided with helpful notes and plenty of practice problems.  Tough course though, you need to keep up with the tutorial problems each week if you don't want to get wrecked by the end (like I did).

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: What seems like a great subject terribly presented, tests have massive weighting and are all or nothing you will either get full marks or nothing for each question.

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: Not entirely unorganised, seems to have improved since last year. The tests however are weighted too heavily, and it IS basically all or nothing when it comes to answering them. Additionally, the test timings are less than convenient, which is surprising because the course coordinator makes it explicitly clear that he is fully aware of it. Not only does it bring the class average down, but your own average suffers greatly from it. I also think the coursebooks are less than stellar, and provide very little aid when it comes to studying. On a lighter note, there are many resources provided in a clear format on Cecil, making it a very handy study tool, and the lecturers do their best to ensure that everyone is learning at the same pace (though not always with the same level of understanding).

MECHENG 242.Name: KSH
Content: The coursebook is a very poor study material as it does not have enough (sometimes none) explanations about the concepts which are taught in the lectures.
Even the lecturers provide very challenging and hard-to-grasp concepts of mechanics with vague explanations.

The timing of the 3 tests were not student-friendly at all. Especially the test 3 was set in the same week where most of the mechanical and mechatronics students had to submit their window-washer projects which have a coursework mark of significant portion in the MECHENG 235 course. So many students did not have any time to study for the test 3, and our class average is clear evidence of that.
To summarise,
- Poor study resources
- Insufficient explanations in the lectures
- Tight schedule of the tests

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: Youtube videos are even more useful than the lectures. Youtube "Structure free'
The course book is useless compare to the civil one which teach the same stuff.
marking of testes are dum. NO STEP MARKS.

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: The last set of lectures were finally understandable, but after having a confusing course book layout and lecturers who were barely understandable for most of the semester it all seemed a little too late. Trying to grasp these concepts is no easy feat, but when you can't even understand the lecturers and when the course book doesn't show clear steps it became nigh on impossible at times. The timing of tests were not ideal as they were always at the end of busy test/assignment weeks, often giving little to no time to study for them. This seems ridiculous considering all the papers are from the same department.

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: A ridiculously unorganised course.

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: Extremely difficult subject to begin with, made even more difficult by the teaching. Still doable with LOTS of self-study, a borrowed textbook and help from Youtube. Marking: It's not all or nothing - I have gotten partial marks on some test questions.

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: Put test 3 the day after 211 test and day before 35% project due for 235. Was not good, average for that test was barely a pass

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: Somebody should show this to the tutors. I doubt they know this exists...

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: This is a fast-paced course with some tricky concepts; keep up with tutorial sheets, else it's hard to catch up again.

This year it didn't appear test questions were marked with an 'all or nothing' approach - maybe things have changed recently. I often received partial marks for questions (just had another look back through my test scripts).
Content was interesting to me, and I thought it was explained really well by the lecturers. You'll get it if you really focus in class - don't sit next to your mates.
Test timings were fine - maybe a bit close to other assignments/tests sometimes but this is just the nature of second year - it's a step up.
The course is pretty much a cross between ENGGEN 121 statics and content that appears early on in CHEMMAT 121.

MECHENG 242.Name: Anonymous
Content: Simon and Raj Das were great, Richard Lin needs to calm down. Content wise everything is connected to each other, you just needa know E = Stress/Strain. Tests were fairly easy but the exam was a step harder and nothing like the tests. Just do all problem sheets and past papers and you're set!
